title: Zac Kyes squiffy grotesque font
content:
Hello

I would love to know what this slightly squiffy grotesque is... from a lovely poster by Zac Kyes...  
thanks for your time and help!

[http://www.modernactivity.com/images/orange.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201185740/http:/www.modernactivity.com/images/orange.jpg)

 [‹ What type is it?](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201185740/http:/typophile.com/node/39622 "Go to previous forum topic") [Looking for the "Golden Compass"/Panera Bread font ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201185740/http:/typophile.com/node/39620 "Go to next forum topic")
author: modernactivity

comments.content:
[Knockout 67](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201185740/http:/typography.com/fonts/font_styles.php?productLineID=100013) is close, but the crossbar on the ’A’ is not low enough.

- Lex

P.S. If this is predigital, it might be some old wood type that hasn’t been digitized yet.

- Lex

It difinitely looks pre-digital judging by the space around the first A in CATASTROPHE.

Nick Cooke

\> <cite>It difinitely looks pre-digital</cite>... Yet it is dated 2005. And [**here**](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201185740/http:/www.zak.to/work/the-living-history-project/) are other uses of the same characters. Interesting.

From the website: <cite>Poster series for photographer Kim Schoen’s exhibition Living History Project for which we commissioned Los Angeles letterpress printers Colby Printing Co.</cite>

- Lex

P.S. “KIM SCHOEN” is Franklin Gothic.

I just found these fonts: My Fonts - Toronto Gothic seems pretty close... sort of pre-digital then vectorized

[http://www.myfonts.com/url?7b881c19c9fbe812789ce2c6d312f01b](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201185740/http:/www.myfonts.com/url?7b881c19c9fbe812789ce2c6d312f01b)
